Award.AwardTitle: Tungsten and Ruthenium Isotopic Study of the Chemical Evolution of Earth
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Earth was likely built as a result of a series of a series of collisions of increasingly larger planetesimals, during the first 50 million years of Solar System history. Growth of the planet largely terminated after a final, giant impact that led to melting of much of the Earth and the creation of the Moon. Surprisingly, there is strong evidence present in the isotopic compositions of some elements in both ancient and young rocks that domains were created within the Earth?s mantle during the primary construction period of the Earth before the giant impact, and these domains have been somehow preserved to the present. This study will examine the tungsten and ruthenium isotopic compositions of rocks derived from these domains to provide new insights to processes occurring within the Earth as it grew, as well as help to constrain the genetic origins of the building blocks of our planet.

Small variations in the abundance of 182-tungsten in terrestrial rocks likely reflects the decay of 182-hafnium, coupled with very early chemical fractionations of the two elements within the silicate portion of the Earth. Prior studies have suggested that modest variations in 182-tungsten among some primitive rocks may reflect processes occurring in early-formed magma oceans. This study will seek to more fully establish the causes of the isotopic heterogeneities, and assess why convective stirring of the mantle has not mixed away the heterogeneities in more than 4.5 billion years. The isotopic composition of Ru varies among planetary bodies in our Solar System as a result of the incorporation of diverse mixtures of nucleosynthetic components. Hence, if the Earth was built from genetically diverse materials, early-formed mantle domains identified by tungsten isotopic variations, may contain ruthenium that is isotopically distinguishable from the dominant composition of the mantle today. If so, the particular building block identified may be tied to a specific type of cosmochemical precursor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this project high-precision, isotopic measurements of the elements tungsten, ruthenium and molybdenum were made for a number of rocks that sample discrete mantle and crustal domains at different times in Earth history. The primary objective of this research was to identify and characterize mantle or crustal rocks that might show unusual isotopic characteristics (here termed ?anomalies? in that the relative abundances of certain isotopes differ from what is normally observed in geological samples). The anomalies identified were then interpreted within a framework of processes that occurred during the first few tens of millions of years of Earth?s existence.

The primary task of this work focused on the search for anomalies with respect to the isotope tungsten-182. Anomalies in this isotope are the result of radioactive decay of the isotope hafnium-182. Hafnium-182 has a short half-life of only ~9 million years, so tungsten-182 anomalies must ultimately reflect processes that occurred within the first ~60 million years of our solar system?s history. This was the interval of time during which Earth?s primary accretion and differentiation into metallic core and silicate mantle occurred.

The primary finding resulting from this project was that tungsten-182 anomalies are present in a number of modern ocean island basalt (OIB) systems, such as Hawaii and Iceland. Surprisingly, the tungsten-182 anomalies correlate with another isotopic indicator of materials that formed in the early Earth and have remained free of subsequent processing, the helium-3/helium-4 ratio. The observed negative correlations between tungsten and helium for volcanic systems like Hawaii, Iceland and Samoa indicate that the basalts of which these islands are built were derived from mantle rocks that likely originally resided deep in the mantle, most likely the core-mantle boundary, 2900 km beneath the surface. The nature of the anomalies most likely indicate that a portion of the tungsten present in some of the basalts is indirectly derived from the Earth?s metallic core, which is believed to have formed within the first 30 million years of solar system history and is presumed to have a strongly anomalous tungsten-182 composition. The indirect process is currently under debate, but may involve isotopic equilibration between metal and silicate.

In all, certain basalts from each of 13 different ocean islands were found to be characterized by anomalous tungsten-182. Some of the islands are known to be underlain by small domains at the core-mantle boundary that are characterized by very slow propagation of seismic waves. These features have been termed ultra-low velocity zones and are strong candidates for the origin of the isotopic anomalies. If true, the research conducted through the funding support of this grant may be the first strong evidence for chemical/isotopic characteristics of the core to be transmitted to the mantle and on to rocks available at the surface. The observations strongly support the "plume" hypothesis that at least some global volcanic ?hotspots? originate from the core-mantle boundary.  

The research conducted with funds from this grant has helped to advance the careers of four early-career female postdoctoral scientists. The grant also enabled the participation of two undergraduates in the project.
